t: Ezekiel 27
A Lament Over Tyre
The*p word of the Lord*s came to me:
“Son of man, take up a lament concerning Tyre.
Say to Tyre, situated at the gateway to the sea, merchant of peoples on many coasts, ‘This is what the Sovereign Lord*s says: “ ‘You*pn say, Tyre, “I*ld am perfect in beauty.”
Your*ln domain was on the high seas; your*ld builders brought your beauty to perfection.
They*ln made all your timbers of*ld juniper from Senir; they*ln took a cedar from Lebanon to*ld make a mast for you.
Of*ln oaks from Bashan they*ld made your oars; of*ln cypress wood from the coasts of Cyprus they*ld made your deck, adorned with ivory.
Fine*ln embroidered linen from Egypt was your sail and*ld served as your banner; your*ln awnings were of blue and purple from*ld the coasts of Elishah.
Men*ln of Sidon and Arvad were your oarsmen; your*ld skilled men, Tyre, were aboard as your sailors.
Veteran*ln craftsmen of Byblos were on board as*ld shipwrights to caulk your seams. All*ln the ships of the sea and their sailors came*ld alongside to trade for your wares.
“ ‘Men*pn of Persia, Lydia and Put served*ld as soldiers in your army. They*ln hung their shields and helmets on your walls, bringing*ld you splendor.
Men*ln of Arvad and Helek guarded*ld your walls on every side; men*ln of Gammad were*ld in your towers. They*ln hung their shields around your walls; they*ld brought your beauty to perfection.
“ ‘Tarshish*p did business with you because of your great wealth of goods; they exchanged silver, iron, tin and lead for your merchandise.
“ ‘Greece,*p Tubal and Meshek did business with you; they traded human beings and articles of bronze for your wares.
“ ‘Men*p of Beth Togarmah exchanged chariot horses, cavalry horses and mules for your merchandise.
“ ‘The*p men of Rhodes traded with you, and many coastlands were your customers; they paid you with ivory tusks and ebony.
“ ‘Aram*p did business with you because of your many products; they exchanged turquoise, purple fabric, embroidered work, fine linen, coral and rubies for your merchandise.
“ ‘Judah*p and Israel traded with you; they exchanged wheat from Minnith and confections, honey, olive oil and balm for your wares.
“ ‘Damascus*p did business with you because of your many products and great wealth of goods. They offered wine from Helbon, wool from Zahar
and casks of wine from Izal in exchange for your wares: wrought iron, cassia and calamus.
“ ‘Dedan*p traded in saddle blankets with you.
“ ‘Arabia*p and all the princes of Kedar were your customers; they did business with you in lambs, rams and goats.
“ ‘The*p merchants of Sheba and Raamah traded with you; for your merchandise they exchanged the finest of all kinds of spices and precious stones, and gold.
“ ‘Harran,*p Kanneh and Eden and merchants of Sheba, Ashur and Kilmad traded with you.
In your marketplace they traded with you beautiful garments, blue fabric, embroidered work and multicolored rugs with cords twisted and tightly knotted.
“ ‘The*pn ships of Tarshish serve as*ld carriers for your wares. You*ln are filled with heavy cargo as*ld you sail the sea.
Your*ln oarsmen take you out*ld to the high seas. But*ln the east wind will break you to pieces far*ld out at sea.

Your*ln wealth, merchandise and wares, your*ld mariners, sailors and shipwrights, your*ln merchants and all your soldiers, and*ld everyone else on board will*ln sink into the heart of the sea on*ld the day of your shipwreck.
The*ln shorelands will quake when*ld your sailors cry out.
All*ln who handle the oars will*ld abandon their ships; the*ln mariners and all the sailors will*ld stand on the shore.
They*ln will raise their voice and*ld cry bitterly over you; they*ln will sprinkle dust on their heads and*ld roll in ashes.
They*ln will shave their heads because of you and*ld will put on sackcloth. They*ln will weep over you with anguish of soul and*ld with bitter mourning.
As*ln they wail and mourn over you, they*ld will take up a lament concerning you: “Who*ln was ever silenced like Tyre, surrounded*ld by the sea?”
When*ln your merchandise went out on the seas, you*ld satisfied many nations; with*ln your great wealth and your wares you*ld enriched the kings of the earth.
Now*ln you are shattered by the sea in*ld the depths of the waters; your*ln wares and all your company have*ld gone down with you.
All*ln who live in the coastlands are*ld appalled at you; their*ln kings shudder with horror and*ld their faces are distorted with fear.
The*ln merchants among the nations scoff at you; you*ld have come to a horrible end and*ld will be no more.’ ”
